document.title: 2021 Minnesota K12 Academic Standards in Social Studies Final

8EFFA21000F64CD0944EC9CDB91A2BFE.description:
Explore how criminality is constructed and how social, political
and legal systems define a person as a criminal, and the
possible impact of that label on individuals and communities.

2E006502E8414B1B83A3AC2369CB5E6C.description:
Ways of Knowing and
Methodologies: Use ethnic and
Indigenous studies methods and
sources in order to understand
the roots of contemporary
systems of oppression and apply
lessons from the past that could
eliminate historical and
contemporary injustices.

7727D05F00A84F5FA102D0FB6E07DDAC.description:
Apply methodologies of fugitivity to map-making, economics
and education.

010DFC1B12FC42B196593C9338145163.description:
Analyze contemporary representations (Indigenous and NonIndigenous) of Indigenous history, iconography, imagery,
symbolism and culture today.

736A172F36574A1EB0FA3C71B66D1011.description:
Evaluate the legacy and lasting effects of the civil rights
movements of the 1960s and 1970s; explain their connections
to current events and concerns.

572F21A231344502B81A5BC210ADAE54.description:

699C0CD75EBA42EDA7428EB949EF7618.description:
Compare and contrast the liberation struggles of people in
different regions of the world that have fought for selfdetermination, liberation, and the empowerment of
disenfranchised and/or marginalized groups.

89786E52747346EA873ECFDE16449B30.description:
Resistance: Describe how
individuals and communities have
fought for freedom and liberation
against systemic and coordinated
exercises of power locally and
globally. Identify strategies or
times that have resulted in lasting
change. Organize with others to
engage in activities that could
further the rights and dignity of
all.

FA3896D882E44E99ABCD9484C49F7DF2.description:
Describe and analyze examples of how religions develop and
change over time in response to differing social, historical, and
political contexts, including, but not limited to,
Shamanism/Animism, Hinduism, Jainism, Buddhism, Sikhism,
Judaism, Christianity, Islam, Indigenous religious traditions in
Africa and the Americas, and African diasporic religions.

56ADF955CE6F47B98E1A6E6DF5BFA877.description:
Identity: Analyze the ways
power and language construct
the social identities of race,
religion, geography, ethnicity,
and gender. Apply these
understandings to oneâ€™s own
social identities and other groups
living in Minnesota, centering
those whose stories and histories
have been marginalized, erased,
or ignored.

1476D9F3226E44A693D61D0FDBFDC562.description:
Examine the impact of U.S. imperialism and foreign policy on
immigration patterns.

38A8B297040241F9961F420CA803B5E2.description:
Investigate how the establishment of the Minnesota and U.S.
government upheld and violated ideas of freedom, equality and
justice for individuals and groups.

802F2F9D804341AEA2E87185DDFEBBA2.description:
Investigate the connection between language and power and
how it has been used for and against various racialized and
ethnic groups.

64ABDE266BC84E2BB236C97A16C7D2B4.description:
Examine the construction of racialized hierarchies based on
colorism and dominant European beauty standards and values.
Examine the construction of hierarchies based on classism,
racism, colorism and dominant beauty standards and values.
